article.text: May 22, 2012 11:54:18 A 5.6-magnitude earthquake has struck Bulgaria's capital Sofia, shaking apartment buildings, rattling windows and causing residents to rush into the streets. Initial reports suggest the quake, which occurred at 3.:00am (local time) on Tuesday, caused no casualties or damage. The US Geological Survey says the earthquake was centred about 24 kilometres west of Sofia and occurred at a relatively shallow depth of 9.4 kilometres. The USGS had initially reported the magnitude as 5.8. Many people in the Bulgarian capital fled their homes and gathered in the streets. "I've never experienced anything like this," said Ivanka Georgieva, who lives on the eighth floor in a residential block. "It was very strong and it was frightening." The quake was felt across the south-western part of Bulgaria. The small Black Sea country of fewer than 8 million people lies in Europe's earthquake-prone Balkan region. The quake comes on the heels of Sunday's 6.0-magnitude earthquake around the northern Italian city of Ferrara that killed six people and reduced homes and historic buildings to rubble. If you have inside knowledge of a topic in the news, contact the ABC News Online Investigative Unit. Australian soldiers discuss how war-torn Afghanistan will fare after troops withdraw in 2014. By business editor Peter Ryan Facebook shares fall well below their issue price as investors unfriend the social network. Barack Obama hopes to become the second Democrat to win two terms as president since WWII. More than 300,000 wheels of cheese lay toppled like dominoes after a quake rocked Italy's north. This service may include material from Agence France-Presse (AFP), APTN, Reuters, AAP, CNN and the BBC World Service which is copyright and cannot be reproduced. AEST = Australian Eastern Standard Time which is 10 hours ahead of UTC (Greenwich Mean Time)
